text: Welcome everybody. Um, I'm here today to
talk about how The Coalition, the Gears
of War franchise, sorry, the home of the
Gears of War franchise, went about
migrating a lot of our Unreal
infrastructure and workflows to Azure.
So, before we get started, hands up.
Who's actually dabbled with, you know,
Unreal in the cloud at all?
Okay, a lot of folks. Awesome. So, most,
which is good. Good. So, hopefully some
of this are familiar. Maybe you might
learn some things as well. So, um,
before we get going, I'll just do a
quick intro of myself. So, my name is
Phil. I am the engine technical director
at the coalition, but I also run a group
at Xbox called the Xbox Games Technology
Group, where we actually look to share a
lot of learnings, tools, technology, and
workflows with other groups, mainly in
Xbox at the moment, but maybe that will
change in the future. If you want to
know more about the Coalition Studio and
what we do, little QR code if you want,
takes us to our website.
Um, a little bit about me. Um, I've been
had a long history in games. Uh I used
to work at a company called Rare in the
UK quite a long time ago. A lot of
history at Xbox about 18 years. Um I've

And I spent a bit of time at Cloudatch
as well, which is a data analytics
platform out of AWS. So but I've got a
lot of experience with Unreal all the
way back to UE2 actually. and I spent
about a decade with U4 U5. So, um, so
here's my agenda for today. I'm going to
set the stage on kind of why we went
about doing this. Um, kind of talking
about how we used to work, some of the

Then a little bit of a kind of digging
into the migration process we went
through. Hopefully, some learnings from

focusing around a lot of the Unreal
based infrastructure and workflows that
folks need to just do their jobs

kind of dig into like, you know, what
did we actually achieve by doing this
whole process? Is it something that's
like, you know, was it worthwhile? What
do we get out of it? Is it something
we're going to continue to do, talk a
little bit about some future projects uh
that we want to take on next, especially
with the cloud in mind. Uh, and then
some learnings and recommendations at

especially with Unreal. And then
depending on timing Q&A, but happily
catch me afterwards, maybe tonight.
Happy to answer questions if you have
any. So, so the background just again
digging into kind of like why did we
start down on this journey. So,
so for background, the coalition is made
of about 350 folks up in Vancouver,
Canada, but we work with a lot of
external partners. Uh, it's roughly 20
at the moment, so there's a lot of
different folks there. Um, and it's
something that we've always done, even
from the original shipping of Gears
Ultimate. Uh, we've always worked with
external partners and it's something
that our team generally keeps in mind.
If we build a piece of tool, piece of
tech, a workflow, we try to think like
how's it going to work when it's at a
different partner site. What do they
need to make this thing function? But
especially pre- pandemic, we're always
like it kind of just work best on our
local network with local things that we
had available to us. And we always tried
to just make it work with external
partners. Um, and it was okay. Um, but
how did we do that? So, to give you like
a visual of how we work, it is pretty
much a 24/7 dev house. We have folks all
over the world. They do different roles
for us from you know different art
roles, different kind of strategic
partners who do a lot of like full codev
with us and they are literally all over
the all over the world. Um one thing to
call out is like this is actually just
where their headquarters are. A lot of
folks who work with us are actually just
at home and they just kind of work
independently and at the coalition as
well we actually work very hybrid. So
you can work in the office, you can work
at home and we have kind of a mix there.
So you know this is you know I've got a
diagram a bit later where it's kind of
more spread out but this is kind of the
main thing that we're dealing with here.
So just to kind of set the stage um and
so the way we used to work is that we
actually deployed things called P4
brokers with Perforce into Azure and
then we went through and actually
connected all of these Perforce brokers
around the world that we generated and
there's generally three of them back to
our main server in Vancouver using what
we call express routes. But with this
system it basically meant that a lot of
our folks actually worked with us had to
set up what's called a Perforce proxy on
their local site which then would
connect back to our main server. And
this is basically the main way that they
got all of the information they needed
like code and content every day. Um, and
the reason kind of I spent a lot of time
just giving you that diagram and that
infrastructure is that 95% of what they
got from us was through Perforce. So
it's not just code, it wasn't just
content, it was all the tools we
distributed that way, logs. We kind of
use Perforce as this general like
transport mechanism, which didn't work
very well back then, but it's just what
we had. And then the big picture we have
in the middle here is actually how we
worked on site out the coalition. So if
you were on prem in the local network,
you got access to great things like a
fileshare DDC. We had like a compute
farm for you. We had everything locally,
but our partners really had nothing like
that. So what we used to have to do was
we had to set up we had the the
peripheral setup, but then we had to do
these kind of very strange setup at
partner sites really just to actually
enable them to work. So we've relied
very heavily on things like a signant
fileshare. We would actually copy a lot
of things from our fileshare to their
fileshare. We'd have to get them to set
up things like a local derived data
cache in Unreal, which is so that they
can actually cache all this information.
They'd have to buy things like
incredible licenses. They'd have to set
up a lot of local compute. A lot of
things basically just to get them up and
running. And if they didn't have these
things, it was a pretty bad time. Um, we
had some things where if a user was
basically by themselves and had none of
this caching infrastructure, you know, a
base shader change, for example, but
could take them out for like 24 hours
because they have to sit there compiling
locally, which is very, very painful. So
um and the big challenge for us was that
a lot of our partners had to basically
you know manage and fund this entire
infrastructure themselves and basically
take a lot of cues from us and it was a
lot of uh kind of back and forth just to
get them set up which is very very
painful. So
um so a lot of challenges came with
this. Our first caveat with that we did
ship a lot of games this way. We shipped
three games this way and it kind of
worked. It was just you know it was a
challenge. So geoloccation was one of
the big challenges we generally faced
where you know because the folks are all
over the world and we're asking them to
set up their own infrastructure. Time
zones were different. It was very very
hard to kind of for our team to stay on
top of kind of like hey how's a partner
doing? They're further away. They're in
a different time zone. Like problems had
to be kind of you know triaged over
email that would take many many days. It
was just a big challenge for us. Uh and
we generally didn't have insights into
like how the local network was set up
and what they were doing. Um bandwidth
was a huge issue especially in UE4 and
kind of our old infrastructure. Our team
would submit like terabytes of data a
day. They would do things like light
bakes submit them in and basically
people would have to sync that uh like
continually through their their perforce
proxies that we talked about. Um and
Unreal has this you know unfortunate way
that if you don't have like code and
data that matches it basically just
breaks all workflows. So if a partner
had a very slow connection or they
couldn't cache things f fast enough,
they essentially had to wait through the
weekend and kind of sync everything just
to get back up and running which was
super super painful. Um we had a lot of
problems with local hardware. So the
idea of like hey could you just go set
up an incredible build farm please so
that you can compile shaders compile
code was just a huge huge challenge for
a lot of folks. Um, and this is where we
did things like our little signant share
where we try to do things like, hey, if
we're making a base shader change, could
we like wrap up the derived data cache
and send it to you so you don't have to
do that compute locally, but that wasn't
always successful. Um, and as I said,
like you know, some of these stalls
could basically take our partners out
for like, you know, hours if not days
when we would do kind of big code
changes and we'd have to do timing, you
know, things of say like, hey, only do a
shader change on a Friday afternoon to
let everyone catch up over the weekend,
for example. So
um with this structure as well support
and observability was super challenging
like if someone had a crash or if we
wanted to get a log from somebody or see
telemetry on like you know hey you're
having a bad time loading our editor it
was really hard to get information out
of them like we would try to do things
like copy files to and from signant make
our little uh you know the editor like
copy files into their local share copy
them over and back again but it was just
a it was pretty pretty challenging to
know and especially if someone was
having like a machine problem we
couldn't really diagnose it easily.
easily without either jumping on a call
late at night, early morning, that kind
of thing. So,
a big thing for us too was
authentication. Like the thing that we
showed you there was that obviously most
of the information you get back and
forth was through Perforce. Uh, and we
used many different layers of
authentication in that way, but we could
never give our partners access through
VPN to our on-prem resources. That was
something that as a company like
Microsoft who we work for, it was a big
taboo and it was a no no. So we actually
really struggled uh to understand like
how we could actually give people access
to things they need like you know Jira
or you know say Unreal Cache or
something like that. So and all of this
just actually resulted in really really
poor on boarding times. So when a
partner came in they did maybe a trial
of like oh cool you know we make amazing
animations for you how fast can we get
them in the project? It was two to four
weeks before we could be like, "Okay,
you've got the infrastructure set up.
You've sunk everything. It's awesome."
But then we had to like diagnose like,
you know, compute problems and like,
"Hey, have you set up properly?" And
like we'd have to have a lot of back and
forth just to, you know, figure out
could they actually function and work on
the projects, you know, successfully.
So,
so with that, we knew how to do
something about this. It was kind of
like I say, it worked. It was
functional. We shipped a bunch of games
that way. But especially post pandemic,
we're like, "Hey, our own team is now
facing this problem. A lot of them are
at home. A lot of them work remotely.
what can we do about this? So with a lot
of the knowledge that um I gained
working at SAS providers like AWS and
Slack, they actually worked very very
differently where they didn't actually
rely on a lot of local infrastructure.
They put a lot of things into the cloud.
So we undertook the process of basically
transforming
uh or kind of doing this infrastructure
transformation to move a lot of our
infrastructure from on-prem to the cloud
and this is how we went about it.
So before we started we wanted to kind
of like you know really really like dig
into some key tenants of like okay what
do we want to do and want to you know
what kind of experience do we want our
users to have. The first one that
especially us and our IT team was like
we have to unify this access mechanism
like it's stupid. We had like six or
seven ways of giving access to people.
It was a pain in the bum. People really
didn't like it. We need to find a way so
that we can give everybody you know
access to what they need very very
quickly with minimal effort and overhead
and management and maintenance. So the
second one was like, you know, talked
about it a little bit earlier. We had
kind of work, you know, what we would
say would be world-class workflows if
you're on prem at the coalition, but we
wanted to make sure that everybody got
that. We want to make sure that everyone
had the most robust and efficient
workflows as possible so they can do
what they do best, make great games. We
wanted that flexibility, which was a big
one. So like even at the coalition, we
are hybrid. So we were like, we need to
support people both in the office, at
home, fully remote. We need to take all
these things into account and everything
should be kind of that first class
citizen at that point. And the last one
which really did bite us quite a lot is
that we need a lot more ways of kind of
measuring workflow efficiency and just
really helping users when things went
wrong. So how could we get more
telemetry out of the systems? How we can
understand like what that optimal
experience looks like and how can we
make sure that everyone is getting
there. So so with this we went through
this big planning phase. This is a
little bit more like Azure specific
because that's what we did. But the good
thing about Azure is actually they've
got this thing called the Microsoft
cloud adoption framework which is
actually a really cool um thing they've
put together for a lot of folks moving
things from onrem to the cloud. So you
know we had some discussions at it we
looked at it and it actually covers a
lot of really key topics that you've got
to be thinking about when you're moving
stuff from on-rem to the cloud. So a big
one is security and identity. A lot of
things that you have on prem are kind of
in a walled garden which is great but
then when you put it up into the cloud
you're like okay who can access this
thing? how are they going to access it?
You know, you know, what does identity
look like at that point? Um, again, our
relationship with our IT team when it
comes to things like governance
management, like you know, usually if
we're things are on prim, the IT team
would provision a machine, give it to
us, and would kind of work that way. But
we have to really think about what roles
do people play when it comes to working
in the cloud and who takes
responsibility of what. It digs into
things like regions, like, you know,
you've got different people in different
locations. Do you need multiple regions?
You need fallbacks, you need things like
availability zones. It kind of digs into
this, which is great. Um, a big one that
we didn't realize until we dug into this
a little bit more was like things like
networking. Like if you've got something
in the cloud, how does it talk to
something on prem? Like if you've got
build machines on your local network,
how does that work? And it digs into
that quite heavily. And you've got to
kind of figure that stuff out too. And
all of this is is wrapped in this kind
of like secure access. We've got to
basically make sure that only the people
we want come in to our infrastructure
and use our infrastructure because a lot
of what people get access to is things
like, you know, the latest Gears Eday
code, for example.
So, and the big thing about this too is
actually we we talked to some partners
and they were like, "Oh, I know a
vendor. They can go and just help you
with this." And our team was like,
"Well, actually, if this is our future,
we should probably do this ourselves.
Like, we should literally go through
this entire process." And it was really
great for my team because they really
did want to be hands-on here. They
wanted to be like, "Okay, if I'm if this
is going to happen and we're going to
maintain in the future, I really want to
get stuck in and actually do this
process myself." And a lot of them had
no clue how to do anything in the cloud
before we started this process. So,
so with that we went through this big
planning phase where we created some
technical papers. Uh, and we did it as a
very phased approach. I think one thing
that was super key when we kind of went
through this is something we called like
an Azure landing zone of like if I'm
going to put something in the cloud,
what have I got to think about like, you
know, where am I going to put like, you
know, credentials and secrets? There's
things like key volts. Okay, got to use
those. How am I going to do like dev and
prod environments like I do locally?
It's like a, you know, two different
machines. Got to look at things like
subscriptions. And we kind of went
through this process and actually then
you know keyed out all these different
things in this space. Identity was a
huge one. We know we had to use unified
model and I'll talk a little bit about
this in a minute. But we know we needed
something to be flexible but super safe
and super secure and we could manage
this a bit more easily.
The big change for us too is actually
Perforce would have to change
traditionally and again I dig in this a
little bit more is like we actually gave
access to Perforce through our own
authentication layer. Don't tell our
security team. Um, and we had to
actually move to something a bit more
unified and actually Helix have
something called the Helix
authentication server which is really
cool and it provides things like single
sign on which again we had to
investigate and figure that out. And
then the big thing for us was actually
going through all of the Unreal
infrastructure and other infrastructure
we had and trying to figure out like
okay like how are we going to migrate
these things? Traditionally they're just
like a service you run on a VM
somewhere. How do I actually move those
things up into the cloud? Uh, and things
like you know there was the fileshare
DDC at the time. There's like things
like compute for like code and shaders.
All these kind of things had to be
considered. And then the last one was
that we actually had a problem at the
coalition too where we we definitely
rely on like an on-prem build farm. Um
and we for a long time wanted to try to
scale into the cloud with build
infrastructure. We didn't actually know
how to do that and how to connect all
those things together. So that was a big
part of this discussion in planning. So
so as part of this and I'll dig into
some of these specifics here. Um and
again this is probably not shouldn't be
seen by my security team but like we had
a lot of different ways of kind of
managing orth and when we went through
and did all this investigation luckily
um out of the box in Azure and I know
there's different versions for different
cloud providers there's something called
Azure Active Directory or Entra and the
idea is we could actually collapse all
of our authentication methods um into
one and this was kind of the winner in
this regard and we could actually make
all the tools technology and
infrastructure including Unreal which
did not support it at the time actually
support Azure Active Director
um which is great. The idea people could
bring their own credentials. We could
actually set all this stuff up and it
became kind of the way of us kind of
merging the different authentication
layers into just that one and that
unified access which was pretty key for
us. The other one for us too and this is
probably a little unique to us but we
were tied very couple very closely to
the Microsoft corporate network because
it's just kind of how we worked but a
lot of what we were trying to do was
kind of like a big no no to the security
folks there. So we actually had to
migrate a lot of our uh internal
networking and actually the tenant we
used already for our uh Perforce brokers
to our own tenant. So we could manage
and govern our own setup. And this is
actually what they suggested anyway. And
it gave us a lot of flexibility to uh
manage things like you know we could
give a VPN if we wanted to but that was
not the case here. We could actually
have things like you know better user
authentication and token expireies. A

cloud and actually set these things up
so that we could work with the
infrastructure we were going to pull
over. So this is a bit crazy chart so I

really important to actually make a

diagram and this came out of that

how does that work? what are the uh you

kind of infrastructure setup we had and

discuss it together um which was you

So actually made it so that when we

We knew what we wanted to do. We knew

Um and the idea is is that we wanted to
basically create this kind of topology
but then replicate it in the cloud in
multiple data centers. Um, and we wanted
to basically move, you know, all most
maybe all of our apps and infrastructure
to be hosted in public Azure and for
everybody regardless of who you are,
partner person working at the coalition
at home to access that through public
Azure with noVPN using kind of the
secure connection and then just give you
access to what you need. Um, and the
idea here was that by replicating in
different data centers, we could bring
all of those resources close to external
teams and they didn't have to go through
the pain of setting this up locally. And
that was the plan here. So,
so with that, we then had to go through
and actually like dig into the actual
application migration process, which was
a little bit more confusing and
something that again it took a little
bit more time and I'm glad we spent the
time doing it. So, we basically went
through all the applications that we ran
on prem today and like who needs access
to this? do the animation team need that
if they're in maybe the far east does
our codev maybe in London need this and
went through and just kind of tried to
figure out of like is it something that
can stay here and doesn't have to
migrate or do we actually need it and
then with that we actually then started
going through and you know every single
application had a deep dive session to
really understand like what does it do
what does it touch does it touch
something over there does it like touch
something like does it write to a
fileshare does it like how do people
interact with it um and then using these
two bits of information we try to
prioritize like what was the biggest
impact we could do um in terms of like
number of applications and in what order
to make sure that again we had the most
impact with our external teams at that
point. And then I think the big thing
that we had to do was like have deep
dive design sessions of like well you
may have set it up like this locally on
say an ISS server with a VM but what
does that look like in the cloud? Like
what's an equivalent? And I think a lot
of that like I've seen a lot of people
go through these conversations and they
say well I can just spin up a VM in the

and just install it and it's it's all
good. I walk away. But we didn't want to

does it you know what does it mean to
have like a code change that supported
like Azure Active Directory? What did it
mean to have things like a virtual
network that can be kind of isolated so
no one can access it? How do we do
proper security? How do we do things
like key vaults? How do we set up like
IA pipelines infrastructure as code so
that we can get away from this kind of
old pattern of like hey it's just a VM
sitting somewhere and I kind of pro it
and poke it sometimes. So this is a
pretty heavy weight thing that we did
here. Um and then you know obviously as
any any good plan is like you sit down
you kind of plan and execute it and we

actually the Unreal Game Sync metadata
service. I appreciate in the current
Unreal infrastructure that's kind of in
hoorde now, but at the time it wasn't.
And we thought like, hey, everyone uses

something that doesn't exist today. You
can't there's no Epic hasn't actually

let's go through that process together

actually, everyone just worked together

um and then you know it's kind of
interesting I just threw up some
questions here. These are kind of
questions we have to start asking
ourselves as part of this application
migration. So you know what is the Azure
equivalent or the cloud equivalent of
the thing I'm running locally? If I'm
running like MSSQL, what's up in what's
what's up in the cloud? How does that
work? Is it SQL server? Is it something
else? Like these are the questions you
have to ask. You know, does your
application read and write to local
storage? How's that going to work? You
don't have local storage in the cloud.
You have maybe have a local VM, but then
how do people get access to that? Again,
something to consider. Um, how do other
applications speak to your application?
Again, you just metadata service is
something that gets, you know, the build
machines, they write to it and say like,
hey, here's a build. Here's some kind of
tagging information. And then all of the
Unreal game syncs read from it. How's
that work? How does, you know, how do
people work with that? Um, you know, do
you need redundancy? And this is
something that we did consider quite a
lot where, you know, like a VM, they can
go down and when it goes down, does it
stop your entire team? So, do you want
to build, you know, redundancy into your
solution and have multiple of these
things running, have them in different
data centers? How does that work? Um,
how are you going to deploy your
application? And again, if you've not
gone down this journey, and I I'll talk
about it at the end a little bit more,
too, but infrastructure as code is your
friend. You don't want to be hand

done in the past. and my team was as bad

it it's cool all good right it's like
well no actually something definitely

how are you going to monitor your

again good things to consider I think uh
when you go on this journey
um and again sorry for the eye chart but
this is kind of the thing that we

tries to answer all those kinds of

TC remote logging service. It's has the
ability to take all telemetry and all

I monitor it with things like app
